lines.text: Enter Provost and a Servant

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: Hes hearing of a cause he will come straight Ill tell him of you.

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: Pray you, do. Ill know His pleasure may be he will relent. Alas, He hath but as offended in a dream! All sects, all ages smack of this vice and he To die fort!
Exit Servant
Enter ANGELO

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Now, whats the matter. Provost

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: Is it your will Claudio shall die tomorrow

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Did not I tell thee yea hadst thou not order Why dost thou ask again

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: Lest I might be too rash: Under your good correction, I have seen, When, after execution, judgment hath Repented oer his doom.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Go to let that be mine: Do you your office, or give up your place, And you shall well be spared.

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: I crave your honours pardon. What shall be done, sir, with the groaning Juliet Shes very near her hour.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Dispose of her To some more fitter place, and that with speed.
Reenter Servant

lines.speaker: servant
lines.text: Here is the sister of the man condemnd Desires access to you.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Hath he a sister

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: Ay, my good lord a very virtuous maid, And to be shortly of a sisterhood, If not already.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Well, let her be admitted. See you the fornicatress be removed: Let have needful, but not lavish, means There shall be order fort.
Exit Servant
Enter ISABELLA and LUCIO

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: God save your honour!

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Stay a little while. Youre welcome: whats your will
To ISABELLA

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: I am a woeful suitor to your honour, Please but your honour hear me.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Well whats your suit

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: There is a vice that most I do abhor, And most desire should meet the blow of justice For which I would not plead, but that I must For which I must not plead, but that I am At war twixt will and will not.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Well the matter

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: I have a brother is condemnd to die: I do beseech you, let it be his fault, And not my brother.

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: [Aside]  Heaven give thee moving graces!

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Condemn the fault and not the actor of it Why, every faults condemnd ere it be done: Mine were the very cipher of a function, To fine the faults whose fine stands in record, And let go by the actor.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: O just but severe law! I had a brother, then. Heaven keep your honour!

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: [Aside to ISABELLA]  Givet not oer so: to him again, entreat him Kneel down before him, hang upon his gown: You are too cold if you should need a pin, You could not with more tame a tongue desire it: To him, I say!

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Must he needs die

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Maiden, no remedy.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Yes I do think that you might pardon him, And neither heaven nor man grieve at the mercy.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: I will not dot.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: But can you, if you would

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Look, what I will not, that I cannot do.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: But might you dot, and do the world no wrong, If so your heart were touchd with that remorse A s mine is to him

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Hes sentenced tis too late.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: [Aside to ISABELLA]  You are too cold.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Too late why, no I, that do speak a word. May call it back again. Well, believe this, No ceremony that to great ones longs, Not the kings crown, nor the deputed sword, The marshals truncheon, nor the judges robe, Become them with one half so good a grace As mercy does. If he had been as you and you as he, You would have slipt like him but he, like you, Would not have been so stern.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Pray you, be gone.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: I would to heaven I had your potency, And you were Isabel! should it then be thus No I would tell what twere to be a judge, And what a prisoner.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: [Aside to ISABELLA] Ay, touch him theres the vein.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Your brother is a forfeit of the law, And you but waste your words.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Alas, alas! Why, all the souls that were were forfeit once And He that might the vantage best have took Found out the remedy. How would you be, If He, which is the top of judgment, should But judge you as you are O, think on that And mercy then will breathe within your lips, Like man new made.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Be you content, fair maid It is the law, not I condemn your brother: Were he my kinsman, brother, or my son, It should be thus with him: he must die tomorrow.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Tomorrow! O, thats sudden! Spare him, spare him! Hes not prepared for death. Even for our kitchens We kill the fowl of season: shall we serve heaven With less respect than we do minister To our gross selves Good, good my lord, bethink you Who is it that hath died for this offence Theres many have committed it.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: [Aside to ISABELLA]           Ay, well said.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: The law hath not been dead, though it hath slept: Those many had not dared to do that evil, If the first that did the edict infringe Had answerd for his deed: now tis awake Takes note of what is done and, like a prophet, Looks in a glass, that shows what future evils, Either new, or by remissness newconceived, And so in progress to be hatchd and born, Are now to have no successive degrees, But, ere they live, to end.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Yet show some pity.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: I show it most of all when I show justice For then I pity those I do not know, Which a dismissd offence would after gall And do him right that, answering one foul wrong, Lives not to act another. Be satisfied Your brother dies tomorrow be content.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: So you must be the first that gives this sentence, And he, that suffers. O, it is excellent To have a giants strength but it is tyrannous To use it like a giant.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: [Aside to ISABELLA]   Thats well said.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Could great men thunder As Jove himself does, Jove would neer be quiet, For every pelting, petty officer Would use his heaven for thunder Nothing but thunder! Merciful Heaven, Thou rather with thy sharp and sulphurous bolt Splitst the unwedgeable and gnarled oak Than the soft myrtle: but man, proud man, Drest in a little brief authority, Most ignorant of what hes most assured, His glassy essence, like an angry ape, Plays such fantastic tricks before high heaven As make the angels weep who, with our spleens, Would all themselves laugh mortal.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: [Aside to ISABELLA]  O, to him, to him, wench! he will relent Hes coming I perceive t.

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: [Aside]  Pray heaven she win him!

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: We cannot weigh our brother with ourself: Great men may jest with saints tis wit in them, But in the less foul profanation.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: Thourt i the right, girl more o, that.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: That in the captains but a choleric word, Which in the soldier is flat blasphemy.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: [Aside to ISABELLA]  Art avised o that more on t.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Why do you put these sayings upon me

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Because authority, though it err like others, Hath yet a kind of medicine in itself, That skins the vice o the top. Go to your bosom Knock there, and ask your heart what it doth know Thats like my brothers fault: if it confess A natural guiltiness such as is his, Let it not sound a thought upon your tongue Against my brothers life.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: [Aside]                  She speaks, and tis Such sense, that my sense breeds with it. Fare you well.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Gentle my lord, turn back.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: I will bethink me: come again tomorrow.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Hark how Ill bribe you: good my lord, turn back.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: How! bribe me

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Ay, with such gifts that heaven shall share with you.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: [Aside to ISABELLA]  You had marrd all else.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Not with fond shekels of the tested gold, Or stones whose rates are either rich or poor As fancy values them but with true prayers That shall be up at heaven and enter there Ere sunrise, prayers from preserved souls, From fasting maids whose minds are dedicate To nothing temporal.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Well come to me tomorrow.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: [Aside to ISABELLA]  Go to tis well away!

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Heaven keep your honour safe!

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: [Aside]Amen: For I am that way going to temptation, Where prayers cross.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: At what hour tomorrow Shall I attend your lordship

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: At any time fore noon.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Save your honour!
Exeunt ISABELLA, LUCIO, and Provost

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: From thee, even from thy virtue! Whats this, whats this Is this her fault or mine The tempter or the tempted, who sins most Ha! Not she: nor doth she tempt: but it is I That, lying by the violet in the sun, Do as the carrion does, not as the flower, Corrupt with virtuous season. Can it be That modesty may more betray our sense Than womans lightness Having waste ground enough, Shall we desire to raze the sanctuary And pitch our evils there O, fie, fie, fie! What dost thou, or what art thou, Angelo Dost thou desire her foully for those things That make her good O, let her brother live! Thieves for their robbery have authority When judges steal themselves. What, do I love her, That I desire to hear her speak again, And feast upon her eyes What ist I dream on O cunning enemy, that, to catch a saint, With saints dost bait thy hook! Most dangerous Is that temptation that doth goad us on To sin in loving virtue: never could the strumpet, With all her double vigour, art and nature, Once stir my temper but this virtuous maid Subdues me quite. Even till now, When men were fond, I smiled and wonderd how.
Exit
